metadata.case_name: Bihar State Mukhtars Association v. Chief Justice and Judges of the Patna High Court

facts.text: Writ petition filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution by Bihar State Mukhtars Association, Patna, and its Vice-President and General Secretary for enforcement of fundamental rights.
Petition heard ex parte as no appearance on behalf of respondents (Chief Justice and Judges of Patna High Court).

Bihar State Mukhtars Association formed about 30 years prior (circa 1931) to protect interests of Mukhtars practising in courts subordinate to Patna High Court under s.3 of Legal Practitioners Act, 1879.
Association passed resolutions at annual conferences to request Patna High Court to remove restriction imposed by r.2; High Court did not remove it.
On July 27, 1958, emergent Executive Committee meeting of Association resolved to move Supreme Court under Art. 32; present petition filed pursuant thereto.

Patna High Court made rules in 1922 under s.11 of Legal Practitioners Act, 1879 (Act XVIII of 1879), including r.2 in Chapter III, Part VII of General Rules and Circular Orders (Civil), 1922, restricting Mukhtars.

Rule 2: 'A Mukhtar shall not be allowed to address any Civil Court except for the purpose of stating the nature and effect of his application or to offer any legal argument or to examine any witness without the leave of the Court specially given.'

Enrolment of Mukhtars under ss.3,6,7 of Legal Practitioners Act, 1879; High Court rules required certificate after passing Mukhtarship examination (subjects under r.10); examination abolished in 1947-48.

s.9 of Act: Every Mukhtar with s.7 certificate may apply to be enrolled in Civil or Criminal Court; on enrolment, practise in such Civil Court and subordinates, and appear, plead, act in Criminal Courts and subordinates, subject to High Court rules.
s.10: No person shall practise as Mukhtar unless holds s.7 certificate and enrolled.
s.11: High Court may make rules declaring functions, powers, duties of Mukhtars in subordinate courts, notwithstanding Code of Civil Procedure.

legal_issues.text: Whether r.2 made by Patna High Court under s.11 of Legal Practitioners Act, 1879, is invalid and void as contravening fundamental right under Art.19(1)(g) of Constitution and not saved by cl.(6) thereof.
Whether impugned r.2 is in excess of powers given to High Court under s.11 of the Act, as it curtails right to practise given by s.9.

petitioner_arguments.text: s.9 gives every enrolled Mukhtar right to practise in Civil Courts (and appear, plead, act in Criminal Courts); s.11 does not empower High Court to curtail this right by rules on functions, powers, duties.
Impugned r.2 curtails right to practise by prohibiting addressing Civil Court except to state nature/effect of application, or offering legal argument or examining witness without special leave.
r.2 is ultra vires s.11 and imposes unreasonable restriction on right to practise any profession under Art.19(1)(g).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.19(1)(g) and cl.(6), Constitution of India; Aswini Kumar Ghosh v. Arabinda Bose

court_reasoning.text: Impugned r.2 is clearly within authority of s.11; ss.9 and 11 must be read together; right to practise under s.9 is not absolute but depends on functions, powers, duties declared by High Court rules under s.11.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Functions, powers and duties are not dissociated from right to practise; High Court can delimit them to regulate practice.

court_reasoning.text: s.9 distinguishes: unlimited right to appear, plead, act in Criminal Courts, but only 'practise' in Civil Courts, subject to s.11 rules.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.11 expression wider than s.15 of Indian Bar Council Act, 1926.

court_reasoning.text: Aswini Kumar Ghosh v. Arabinda Bose distinguished: there, no express statutory reservation of rulemaking power to curtail right; here, s.11 expressly reserves power to declare functions, powers, duties.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.11 expressly enables regulation of Mukhtars' practice rights.

court_reasoning.text: No challenge to constitutional validity of s.11 itself; if r.2 intra vires, no violation of fundamental rights.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Right to practise created by Act and regulated thereby.

holdings.text: Impugned r.2 is intra vires s.11 of Legal Practitioners Act, 1879; does not violate Art.19(1)(g).
ss.9 and 11 read together; High Court empowered to regulate Mukhtars' functions, powers, duties, thereby delimiting right to practise.

precedents_cited.case_name: Aswini Kumar Ghosh v. Arabinda Bose
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguished as no express statutory power to curtail practice right there, unlike s.11 here.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition under Art.32 for enforcement; challenge to rule as violating Art.19(1)(g) not saved by cl.(6).

statutes_cited.name: Legal Practitioners Act, 1879
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs enrolment, practice rights, and High Court rulemaking for Mukhtars' functions, powers, duties.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Bar Council Act, 1926
statutes_cited.relevance: Compared; narrower power than s.11 of 1879 Act.

statutes_cited.name: Supreme Court Advocates (Practice in High Courts) Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Interpreted in Aswini Kumar Ghosh; right to practise unless expressly curtailed by statute.

outcome.summary: Court held impugned r.2 intra vires s.11 of Legal Practitioners Act; no violation of Art.19(1)(g); petition rejected ex parte.

key_quotes.text: "The simple question for decision really is this: is the impugned rule in excess of the powers given to the High Court under s.11 of the Act?"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Sections 9 and 11 of the Act must be read together and it would be wrong to treat the right to practise given by s.9 as dissociated from the functions, powers and duties of Mukhtars referred to in s.11."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to rejecting petitioner's distinction and upholding rule.

key_quotes.text: "It seems to us that the impugned rule is clearly within that authority."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Direct holding on vires of r.2.
